attributes.comment:
I am writing to protest the proposed fee increases outlined in Docket ID USCIS-
2006-0044, specifically the the following petitions: the fees for the I-600/600A
Petition to Classify Orphan as an Immediate Relative will increase from $545
to $670, the fees for the N-565 Application for Replacement of Certificate of
Citizenship (used for name changes) will increase from $220 to $380, the fees for
the N-600 Application for Certificate of Citizenship will increase from $255 to $460,
and the fees for the Biometric Services (fingerprints) will increase from $70 to $80.
First, a 66% increase in fees, especially on this broad a scope, seems to be an
incredibly large jump. While most citizens understand the need for increased
security costs more money that must be raised from somewhere, a jump this
large does not seem justified without evidence of attempts to try and streamline
many processes that seems repetitive and wasteful. For example, in the case of
the I-600/600-A processing, many countries such as China, have a wait that is
longer than the 18 month time period that the petition is valid. However, instead of
a simplified renewal when the wait for a child goes beyond 18 months, the adoptive
parent must refile a brand new petition, paying full fees and resulting in wasted
manpower by processing it as a completely new application. A streamlined
process would require less time and manpower from the USCIS and less money
for the citizen applying for this petition.
Further, while these increased fees would provide more money to be used for
stronger enforcement of immigration law, it would place the burden for these fees
on the immigrants who are trying to comply with the law as they are required. I
fear that these fees will make the burden of these fees so onerous that they will
have the opposite effect--increasing the number of illegal immigrants because the
fees are beyond what many can afford, so there will be even more dollars needed
for enforcement in the long run.
It does not feel proper or fair to increase these fees without taking a hard look at
the current processes at hand to make sure that the multiple changes
experienced in recent years by the USCIS have not left inefficient processes in
place that wasted the dollars paid by both citizens and legal immigrants. As both
a taxpayer and the parent of naturalized US citizen, this proposal seems unfair
and poorly thought out.
Thank you for your attention,
Margaret Doss
attributes.title: Comment Submitted by Margaret Doss
